subject: Re: [junit] Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methods
msgSnippet: Just an observation, but it seems that option 6 could be achieved simply by placing the mock classes in a separate, but parallel, package directory structure
messageBody:
Just an observation, but it seems that option 6 could be achieved simply
by placing the mock classes in a separate, but parallel, package
directory structure as the "real" classes and then placing the mock
directory structure ahead of the real directory structure in the CLASSPATH.

For example...

/projects/src/com/xyz/
/projects/src/mock/com/xyz/

CLASSPATH=/projects/src/mock:/projects/src

From the perspective of the classloader, the mock objects *are* the
real objects.

Mike

--
Mike Clark
Clarkware Consulting, Inc.

Development, and Performance Consulting
http://www.clarkware.com

Matt Caswell wrote:

> Very interesting. It seems to me that you could use 1-5 in certain
> circumstances. However I think I would be reluctant to change the way my
> code was implemented just so that I could test it, as some of the other
> posts on this topic have suggested you should do. Option 6 looks like it
> could have a lot of potential - I would think it would work in almost all
> scenarios without requiring that you write your implementation code in a
> specifc way. I agree - it definately looks like a fun thing to try and do!
>
> Matt

>
> There are several was to get Mock objects into your production code:
>
> 1. Parameters
>
> As Mr Freeman shows, you use parameters to pass the Mock into the
> class that calls it.
>
> 2 Reflection
>
> If B is referenced in a field of A, you can use reflection to modify
> A and replace B with it's Mock.
>
> 3 Mole Pattern
>
> Subclass A, and use the subclass to setup the Mock. [I call this
> design the "Mole Pattern"]
>
> 4 Strategy Pattern
>
> Use a Strategy design pattern.
>
> 5 Dynamic Proxy
>
> If the B is an implementation of an Interface, you can use a Dynamic
> Proxy (new feature of Java 1.3b). The Mock would be an
> InvocationHandler, instead of a twin of B.
>
> 6 Classloader
>
> Use a classloader to load the Mock instead of the real class.
>
> ---
>
> There may be other options, but these are the ones I've heard of.
> Personally, I've used everything except #6. Options #1 (parameters)
> and #2 (reflection) are my favorites. They are usually the easiest
> to implement and understand. For #2, I've used the
> PrivilegedAccessor.java [posted by Mr DiIorio] to make the reflection
> work simple.
>
> I've never seen anyone use #6 (classloaders), I think it would be fun
> to try.
>
> - Greg
>
>
> --- In junit@y..., "Steve Freeman" <steve@m...> wrote:
>
>> RE: Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methodsAlternatively,
>> change from:
>>
>> public class A {
>> public void f() {
>> b = new B();
>> b.doSomething();
>> }
>> }
>>
>> to:
>>
>> public class A {
>> public void f(B b) {
>> b.doSomething(aValue());
>> }
>> }
>>
>> The test then becomes:
>>
>> public class TestA {
>> public void testF() {
>> A anA = new A(aValue);
>> MockB mockB = new MockB();
>> mockB.setExpectedSomething(aValue);
>>
>> a.f(mockB);
>>
>> mockB.verify();
>> }
>> }
>>
>> We have found that changing to a style where you pass behaviours
>
> around, rather than data, avoids things like subclassing production
> code in a test and pushes the code to flexing in the 'right' kinda
> ways. If you can figure out what to pass in and what to verify, then
> the rest of the test usually falls out.
>
>> Steve
